author: By Dwight Garner
title: Emotions Haunt a Man for Life in Cynthia Ozick’s Tragicomic ‘Antiquities’
description: In Ozick’s new novella, an elderly man recalls his alienation at a boarding school decades before and his friendship with a Jewish classmate.
content: Cynthia Ozick’s new novella, “Antiquities,” is set in Westchester County, New York, in 1949 and 1950. It’s about seven semi-distinguished old men: Waspy geezers, with walkers and heart conditions, the last living trustees of a patrician boys’ academy that closed more than three decades earlier. They live on the splendid property, their number dwindling, and they bicker like sunburned children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Vanessa Bryant Uses Her Platform to Battle the Powerful
description: Through social media and a lawsuit, she is trying to hold law enforcement to account in ways that are uncommon for women, and especially for women of color.
content: For years, under the power dynamics of Los Angeles policing, many victims who have accused powerful law enforcement institutions of wrongdoing have found their charges batted aside or buried in bureaucratic inertia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sternbergh
title: Brooklyn Man Finds New Life in Crime (Writing)
description: Jonathan Ames, known for his confessional essays and TV shows like “Bored to Death,” tries his hand at a detective novel with “A Man Named Doll.”
content: It was over lunch in 2013 that the literary agent Eric Simonoff asked Jonathan Ames, “So what do you want to do with your writing career?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Vegetables Get the Ripert Treatment
description: The latest cookbook from the chef of Le Bernardin focuses on simple, but stunning recipes for seasonal produce.
content: Eric Ripert’s new collection of vegetable recipes is maybe one of the least seemingly chef-driven cookbooks. And it holds true to its title, “Vegetable Simple.” What a delightful approach, especially with summer on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: U.S. health officials are examining ‘a handful’ of new, unconfirmed reports after J.& J. vaccine pause, the C.D.C. director says.
description: Officials are trying to determine whether the reports might be cases of a rare, serious blood clotting disorder. It’s unclear whether the vaccine was responsible for the original cases.
content: Federal health officials are investigating “a handful” of new, unconfirmed reports that have emerged after Johnson & Johnson injections were paused nationwide, to determine whether they might be cases of a rare, serious blood clotting disorder that caused the pause, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Monday. It is unclear as yet whether the vaccine was responsible for the original few cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Richard Rush, Who Directed ‘The Stunt Man,’ Dies at 91
description: He was nominated for an Oscar for the movie, about filmmaking stunts, perception and reality. His earlier films were aimed at the teenage market.
content: Richard Rush, who made rebellious-youth films in the 1960s that featured emerging stars like Jack Nicholson but who had his biggest success in 1980 with “The Stunt Man,” a quirky, expectation-defying thriller that gained cult status, died on April 8 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: As the Chauvin Trial Closes, Will Seeing Be Believing?
description: A case that began with video that shook the world ends with arguments over what story those images told.
content: After weeks of testimony and months of anguish, the arguments in the trial of Derek Chauvin came down to: Should you believe your eyes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How the Johnson & Johnson Vaccine Pause Affects New York
description: A program to vaccinate homebound older people was put on hold while the one-shot vaccine was paused.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Irrational Covid Fears
description: Why do so many vaccinated people remain fearful? Listen to the professor’s story.
content: Guido Calabresi, a federal judge and Yale law professor, invented a little fable that he has been telling law students for more than three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: U.N. Reports Surge of Migrant Children Entering Mexico, Destined for U.S.
description: The number of children arriving in Mexico seeking to cross into the United States increased ninefold from January to March 2021. Some 275 arrive each day.
content: MEXICO CITY — The number of migrant children arriving in Mexico and hoping to enter the United States has increased ninefold from January to March this year, the U.N. Children’s Fund said Monday, with an average of 275 minors entering the country every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: There’s a Name for the Blah You’re Feeling: It’s Called Languishing
description: The neglected middle child of mental health can dull your motivation and focus — and it may be the dominant emotion of 2021.
content: At first, I didn’t recognize the symptoms that we all had in common. Friends mentioned that they were having trouble concentrating. Colleagues reported that even with vaccines on the horizon, they weren’t excited about 2021. A family member was staying up late to watch “National Treasure” again even though she knows the movie by heart. And instead of bouncing out of bed at 6 a.m., I was lying there until 7, playing Words with Friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Yana Paskova
title: They Told Her Women Couldn’t Join the Ambulance Corps. So She Started Her Own.
description: Judge Rachel Freier has helped dozens of Orthodox Jewish women in New York City get training and start work as emergency medical technicians. In doing so, she challenged her community’s conception of the role women can play in public and professional life.
content: — Charna Goldsmith, an E.M.T. with the group Ezras Nashim
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nambi Ndugga and Austin Frakt
title: What’s Behind the Growth in Alcohol Consumption?
description: A comparison across demographic groups over two decades offers some clues, and there has been a particular rise in misuse among women during the pandemic.
content: American deaths from misuse of substances, including alcohol, have increased over the past two decades, but not uniformly across various demographic groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
title: Biden, debating exit from Afghanistan, rejected generals’ views.
description: Over two decades of war, the Pentagon had fended off the political instincts of elected leaders frustrated with the grind of Afghanistan. But President Biden refused to be persuaded.
content: President Biden used his daily national security briefing on the morning of April 6 to deliver the news that his senior military leaders suspected was coming. He wanted all American troops out of Afghanistan by Sept. 11, the 20th anniversary of the attacks on New York and the Pentagon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Santaniello
title: College Players Graduating to the N.H.L. Have a Chance for Longer Test Run
description: The modified schedule gives college players who make N.H.L. rosters an opportunity to play more than just the handful of games they’d get in a traditional season.
content: Each spring as college hockey seasons conclude, several top players — highly drafted underclassmen and free agents, for the most part — quickly progress to the professional ranks. But there’s a bonus for those players this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Prosecutor in Derek Chauvin trial makes closing argument: ‘This wasn’t policing, this was murder.’
description: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer.
content: In his last comments to jurors before they begin deliberating over a verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial, a Minnesota prosecutor argued that Mr. Chauvin had acted with cruelty and indifference unbefitting of a police officer and should be convicted of murder in George Floyd’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Should There Be Separate Social Media Apps for Children?
description: Would an Instagram for children make social media safer for young users? Or would it hook them even earlier?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Navalny’s doctors fear the worst.
content: Aleksei Navalny, the imprisoned Russian dissident, “could die at any moment,” his personal doctors said. Mr. Navalny, who last year survived an attempted poisoning, is now in the third week of a hunger strike over his medical treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hetty McKinnon
title: This Vegan Ramen Maximizes Flavor and Time
description: The rich, creamy broth in this tantanmen tastes like it’s been cooked much longer.
content: With most ramen, the work that’s put into the broth is what makes all the difference, providing the foundation for the entire dish. A broth made with pork, chicken or seafood can be cooked for up to three days, resulting in an intense, velvety soup that sings with complex, multilayered flavors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Officer Attacked in Capitol Riot Died of Strokes, Medical Examiner Rules
description: The determination is likely to complicate efforts to prosecute anyone in the death of the officer, Brian Sicknick.
content: WASHINGTON — Officer Brian D. Sicknick of the U.S. Capitol Police had multiple strokes hours after sparring with a pro-Trump mob during the Jan. 6 riot and died of natural causes, Washington’s medical examiner said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Shortages and mounting death tolls in India’s second wave.
content: Delhi enacted a weeklong citywide lockdown on Monday, as coronavirus infections and deaths in India reported new daily records and several local governments announced they were facing shortages of oxygen, I.C.U. beds and treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil makes a pitch for capturing emissions and a carbon price.
description: The oil company wants to create a profit-making business out of the capture of carbon emitted by petrochemical plants and other industries.
content: HOUSTON — Under growing pressure from investors to address climate change, Exxon Mobil on Monday proposed a $100 billion project to capture the carbon emissions of big industrial plants in the Houston area and bury them deep beneath the Gulf of Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: U.S. Readies Small-Business Grants as P.P.P. Nears End
description: New programs for restaurants and live-event businesses will soon start taking applications as the Paycheck Protection Program winds down.
content: The federal government is preparing to open two new industry-specific small-business relief programs, one of them months in the works, as its signature pandemic aid effort, the Paycheck Protection Program, nears its end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Stroman Dominates for Eight Innings in Win Over Rockies
description: Marcus Stroman pitched well and helped himself with a spectacular defensive play. The Mets have won five of six.
content: DENVER — Marcus Stroman pitched eight innings of one-run ball and made a dazzling defensive play, catcher James McCann threw out Trevor Story as he attempted to steal second for the final out and the Mets beat the Colorado Rockies, 2-1, on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Facebook, preparing for Chauvin verdict, to limit posts that might incite violence.
description: The company said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
content: Facebook on Monday said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd, to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: My Daughter and I Are Trapped in Brazil’s Tragedy
description: We spend our days watching ambulances, as Covid-19 rips through the country.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — From the balcony of my apartment, I can see an ambulance parking lot. For over a year now, my 2½-year-old daughter and I have been monitoring — avidly, anxiously — the movements of the 10 ambulances parked there. That’s the sort of entertainment we have now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Apple says Parler can return to iPhones after the app makes some changes.
description: Parler had been kicked off iPhones and Android devices after the Capitol insurrection in January.
content: Parler, the social network popular with conservatives, is making its comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nilo Tabrizy and Débora Souza Silva
title: Watching the Derek Chauvin Trial With Families Affected by Police Violence
description: What happened to George Floyd is the latest in a long line of incidents of police violence captured on camera. We watched the Chauvin trial with the families of Rodney King, Oscar Grant and Stephon Clark to see this moment in history through their eyes.
content: “I don’t watch the footage of my dad’s incident because it is torture,” said Lora Dene King, whose father, Rodney G. King, was brutally beaten by the police in Los Angeles. “Here it is 30 years later and nothing has changed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Minneapolis Public Schools to close in-person learning later this week in anticipation of a verdict.
description: The schools will shift to remote learning from Wednesday through Friday, but if the schedule in the Derek Chauvin trial changes, the district will “re-evaluate, adjust plans,” a letter to parents said.
content: Minneapolis Public Schools will shift to remote learning later this week in anticipation of the verdict in the Derek Chauvin trial, Ed Graff, the district superintendent, said in a notice sent to the school community last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greece relaxes some quarantine rules as it prepares to welcome back tourists.
description: ATHENS — As part of a plan to revive its crucial tourism sector, Greece is lifting quarantine restrictions beginning Monday for arrivals from European Union member states and several other countries including the United States and Britain.
content: ATHENS — As part of a plan to revive its crucial tourism sector, Greece is lifting quarantine restrictions beginning Monday for arrivals from European Union member states and several other countries including the United States and Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arden Fanning Andrews
title: Michael Musto, Lynn Yaeger and Mickey Boardman: Friends for Life
description: The longtime crew has been all around New York together and witnessed the city remake itself time and again. What’s endured is its members’ bonds with one another.
content: It was Manhattan’s print journalism scene that served as matchmaker to the Paper magazine editor at large Mickey Boardman, the writer Lynn Yaeger and the columnist Michael Musto, who have been friends for over 25 years and dedicated New Yorkers for even longer. In the early ’90s, Yaeger, then the fashion editor at The Village Voice, assigned a story to Musto that never made it to press. “My article was so appalling she didn’t run it, but then we became friends, partly out of gossip and partly because we were on a lot of the same lists for parties,” says Musto. He met Boardman in 1994, after receiving an invite to Paper’s 10th-anniversary bash. “Michael and Bill Cunningham were, to me, the legendary documenters of downtown culture,” says Boardman, who was subsequently introduced to Yaeger by Lauren Ezersky, the host of the television series “Behind the Velvet Ropes,” after she spotted the two aboard a long-since-retired Fashion Week bus that carried attendees from show to show. That bus is a good metaphor for what their friendship became: “It was uptown, downtown, Midtown, everywhere,” says Musto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Jason Karaian
title: JPMorgan draws public ire for financing a breakaway European soccer league.
description: The bank’s role has made it one of the targets for criticism. European heads of state, former players and supporter groups of the clubs involved were among those speaking out against the plan.
content: European soccer fans are known for their intense passion for the sport. Now, they are aiming their ire at the American banking giant JPMorgan Chase for backing the so-called Super League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: lamentable
description: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Minnesota students walk out of schools in solidarity with the racial justice movement.
description: The organizers of the walkout, Minnesota Teen Activists, said that students at more than 100 schools participated.
content: Students streamed out of schools across Minnesota on Monday afternoon to protest racial injustice, in a coordinated action that coincided with closing arguments in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with killing George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: How Much Sway Does the N.R.A. Still Have?
description: The group’s lobbying power is diminished — but that hasn’t shaken Republican opposition to gun control.
content: The National Rifle Association, for decades among the most powerful political groups in the country, is on the rocks. Its president, Wayne LaPierre, has acknowledged secretly taking the N.R.A. into bankruptcy, and its lobbying apparatus is badly diminished as the organization has lost, in Mr. LaPierre’s own private estimation, over $100 million as a result of legal troubles. It’s currently facing suits from New York and the District of Columbia accusing the group of abusing its nonprofit status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins
title: Minneapolis law enforcement agencies and community groups call for peaceful protests after a verdict.
description: The Minneapolis police chief, Medaria Arradondo, said that the police response after a decision would be grounded in “de-escalation.”
content: After several nights of protests against a police killing in nearby Brooklyn Center, Minneapolis law enforcement agencies and community groups asked for peace during a news briefing Monday, as the trial against the former police officer Derek Chauvin comes to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Rory Smith
title: Europe’s New Super League, Explained
description: Whether you’re a lifelong fan or an outsider who doesn’t know your Manchesters from your Madrids, we’ve got answers to your pressing questions.
content: A little more than a year after European soccer found a renewed sense of unity in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, the sport now faces its greatest crisis in a generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Looted Objects From Afghanistan Are Returned
description: Thirty-three antiquities were handed over to the Afghan ambassador by the Manhattan district attorney’s office and the Department of Homeland Security.
content: For half a century, through war, anarchy and upheaval, Afghanistan has been stripped of tens of thousands of Buddhist and Hindu antiquities, some dating back more than 1,800 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Abandoning Afghanistan Is a Historic Mistake
description: Leaving proves Osama bin Laden right: Eventually, America cuts and runs.
content: I once boarded a flight from Dubai to Kabul alongside a team of Afghan soccer players — teenage girls in red uniforms, chatting and laughing much as they might have anywhere else in the world. I thought of those players again after President Biden announced plans for America’s complete military withdrawal from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Harris visits North Carolina to promote Biden’s infrastructure plan, saying it will create ‘good jobs.’
description: The vice president discussed a $20 billion investment the administration is proposing to convert the country’s entire fleet of gasoline and diesel-powered school buses to electric vehicles.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris traveled to North Carolina on Monday to promote the Biden administration’s $20 billion proposal to convert the country’s entire fleet of gasoline- and diesel-powered school buses to electric vehicles, and to talk up the president’s plans to create “good jobs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: American Airlines’ chief explains his opposition to restrictive voting laws.
description: Doug Parker, the C.E.O., said in a meeting with employees that voting rights was “an equity issue,” according to a recording of the conversation.
content: The American Airlines chief executive, Doug Parker, spoke to workers last week about his decision to publicly oppose restrictive voting legislation pending in Texas, saying that people of color feel “as though these laws are making it much harder for people like them to vote.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Popkin and Erin Schaff
title: There’s a Booming Business in America’s Forests. Some Aren’t Happy About It.
description: The fuel pellet industry is thriving. Supporters see it as a climate-friendly source of rural jobs. For others, it’s a polluter and destroyer of nature.
content: GARYSBURG, N.C. — In 2013, Kathy Claiborne got a noisy new neighbor. That’s when a huge factory that dries and presses wood into roughly cigarette-filter-sized pellets roared to life near her tidy home in one of the state’s poorest counties. On a recent afternoon in her front yard, near the end of a cul-de-sac, the mill rumbled like an uncomfortably close jet engine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter van Agtmael
title: Night Crossings: Scenes From the U.S.-Mexico Border
description: Border crossings are at their highest levels in 15 years.
content: ROMA, Texas — Shortly after sunset, there are signs of life on an isolated riverbank outside the border town of Roma, Texas. Over on the Mexican shore of the Rio Grande, flickering lights appear through the trees for a moment, then disappear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Why the Knicks Keep, Ahem, Winning
description: The recently awful Knicks have won six straight behind the All-Star Julius Randle, vintage play from Derrick Rose and tough team defense.
content: It was only an overtime victory over the New Orleans Pelicans, the kind of win even pessimistic Knicks fans would have thought possible going into the season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: N.Y.P.D. to Limit Use of ‘Sound Cannon’ on Crowds After Protesters’ Lawsuit
description: The Police Department has agreed to stop using an “alert” noise on the devices after demonstrators and photographers sued, saying it caused migraines and dizziness.
content: Police officers first deployed the earsplitting beeps against protesters more than a decade ago in Pittsburgh: Painfully loud noises emitted from a powerful speaker atop a police vehicle, a crowd-control device known informally as a “sound cannon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jerry Lee Albin, Who Found Sobriety After a Hard Life, Dies at 75
description: Mr. Albin put drugs, prison and biker gangs behind him, started a construction business and counseled prisoners. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed Faces Criticism as It Wades Into Climate and Equity Issues
description: The Federal Reserve is proudly politically independent. That makes key discussions around climate change and racial inequity a balancing act.
content: In mid-2019, Jerome H. Powell fielded a question from reporters that he often faced in those days: Were politics, and particularly a pressure campaign coming from Donald J. Trump’s White House to cut interest rates, influencing the Federal Reserve’s policy stance?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: A.C.L.U. Asks Supreme Court to Let It Seek Secret Surveillance Court Rulings
description: A prominent Republican — Ted Olson — backed the request for high court review of a spy court ruling, which would be the first of its kind.
content: WASHINGTON — The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Supreme Court on Monday to unlock the doors to the nation’s foreign intelligence wiretapping court, arguing that Americans have a First Amendment right to ask its judges to disclose secret rulings affecting their privacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: A confused federal effort to retrieve Americans overseas in the initial outbreak led to safety risks, a new report says.
description: The federal report concluded that the evacuation of Americans from China bogged down badly as different divisions within the federal health department argued over which was responsible.
content: The government’s confused effort to retrieve Americans overseas during the early weeks of the coronavirus outbreak compromised the safety of the evacuees, federal employees and communities near where Americans returned to, according to a new report published on Monday by Congress’s nonpartisan watchdog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: The designated hitter, or D.H., is a player on a baseball team whose sole job is to hit in place of the pitcher. The rule was introduced in 1973, in an effort to increase the overall hitting performance of the American League. It worked, and batting averages jumped the following season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes, Madeleine Ngo and Eileen Sullivan
title: Adults in all U.S. states are now eligible for vaccination, hitting Biden’s target. Half have had at least one dose.
description: Hawaii, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Oregon, Rhode Island and Vermont were the last states to expand eligibility on Monday. More than 131 million Americans have received at least one shot of a Covid-19 vaccine.
content: All adults in every U.S. state, Washington, D.C., and Puerto Rico are now eligible for a Covid-19 vaccine, meeting the April 19 deadline that President Biden set two weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rosen
title: The Science of Climate Change Explained: Facts, Evidence and Proof
description: Definitive answers to the big questions.
content: The science of climate change is more solid and widely agreed upon than you might think. But the scope of the topic, as well as rampant disinformation, can make it hard to separate fact from fiction. Here, we’ve done our best to present you with not only the most accurate scientific information, but also an explanation of how we know it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Amid Biden Climate Push, a Question Looms: Is America’s Word Good?
description: After four years of “America First,” the president tries this week to reclaim U.S. leadership in the fight against climate change. Can the world trust his promises?
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden faces a fundamental question as he convenes heads of state this week in a virtual summit to declare that the United States is ready to reclaim a leadership role in the fight against climate change: Is America’s word still any good?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seligson
title: She Caters to Women but Doesn’t Hire for Gender. Meet Rosewood’s C.E.O.
description: With kids’ camps and postpartum wellness programs aimed at affluent millennials, Sonia Cheng has steered her luxury hotel group through the pandemic storm.
content: — Sonia Cheng, chief executive, Rosewood Hotel Group
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Minnesota Governor Calls Alleged Assaults on Journalists ‘Chilling’
description: Gov. Tim Walz said he had told police officers to “make changes” that would allow reporters to do their jobs.
content: Tim Walz, the governor of Minnesota, on Sunday responded to reports that the state’s police officers had assaulted journalists covering the unrest in a Minneapolis suburb, saying, “Apologies are not enough; it just cannot happen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: India faces new lockdowns plus oxygen and drug shortages as cases spiral, and other news from around the world.
description: The city of Delhi is beginning a week of restrictions, as local governments there and elsewhere struggle to cope with a second wave of the coronavirus.
content: NEW DELHI — Delhi enacted a weeklong citywide lockdown on Monday, as infections and deaths in India hit new daily records and several local governments, including in the national capital, reported shortages of oxygen, beds and drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Back Limits on Green Cards
description: The justices heard arguments on whether immigrants with “temporary protected status” who entered the country illegally may apply for lawful permanent residency.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed ready on Monday to rule that immigrants allowed to stay in the United States temporarily for humanitarian reasons may not apply for green cards if they had entered the country unlawfully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A 1922 Wallace Neff house in Montecito, a Joseph Eichler midcentury home in Palo Alto and a 2005 Mediterranean townhouse in Huntington Beach.
content: This house was designed by the architect Wallace Neff for John Willis Baer, the president of Occidental College from 1906 to 1916, and incorporates Spanish and Mediterranean elements. Original tiles throughout the house remain intact, as does an elevated platform in the living room designed to be occupied by musicians during large parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: The White House is defending an about-face on the number of refugees the U.S. admits.
description: Jen Psaki says the Biden administration is trying to figure out how to process more refugees.
content: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, on Monday defended the administration’s decision to keep the number of refugees allowed into the country at the level set by the Trump administration, a move last week that prompted immediate criticism by Democrats and an about-face by President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: ‘God Knows What’s Going to Happen’: Minneapolis Braces for Verdict in Floyd’s Death
description: Businesses boarded up and residents held their breath, fearing a repeat of last year’s unrest if the jury brings back a decision that the public sees as unjust.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Around midday last Monday, Samir Patel received a phone call from his friend, a dentist: Gunshots had rung out, his friend told him, and the contractors who were rebuilding the office he lost in last year’s unrest had fled. He was boarding up, and he told Mr. Patel he should move quickly to protect his own business, a dry cleaning shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: We Need to Talk About Cancel Culture
description: Trevor Noah, Kara Swisher, Jane Coaston and Ezra Klein debate the merits and dangers of cancel culture, and share a sneak peek at upcoming episodes from Opinion Audio.
content: Times subscribers can R.S.V.P. for this free event, Wednesday, May 12 at 7 p.m. Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

title: France Enabled 1994 Rwanda Genocide, Report Says
description: A report commissioned by the Rwandan government accuses France of enabling the genocide of at least 800,000 people and of withholding “critical documents and testimony.”
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — France played a “significant” role in “enabling a foreseeable genocide” in Rwanda, according to a report commissioned by the Rwandan government that was released Monday and that echoed the findings of a recent appraisal by France.

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Progressives Propose Tripling Housing Commitment in Infrastructure Plan
description: The proposal, called the Green New Deal for Public Housing Act, is a marker for liberals as Democrats seek to influence President Biden’s $2.3 trillion public-works package.
content: WASHINGTON — Top liberal lawmakers unveiled legislation on Monday that would pour more than $100 billion over a decade into modernizing the public housing system and starting a transition to renewable energy, as progressives seek to prod President Biden to expand his far-reaching infrastructure plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: U.S. to Begin Offering Vaccines to Detainees at Guantánamo Bay
description: The plan, initiated during the Trump administration, had been delayed after a political and public outcry.
content: The United States military began offering to vaccinate the detainees at Guantánamo Bay on Monday in an effort to protect troops stationed there and help restart the stalled war crimes hearings, an administration official with knowledge of the Pentagon plan said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Panel Is Scathing in Its Criticism of a British Report on Race
description: The criticism adds to a backlash against findings by the Johnson government that called Britain a “model for other white-majority countries.”
content: GENEVA — United Nations human rights experts on Monday issued a devastating critique of a report on race published last month by the British government, accusing its authors of repackaging racist tropes, distorting history and normalizing white supremacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Health Agencies Compromised Safety of Evacuees and Staff Early in Pandemic, Watchdog Says
description: A new report from the Government Accountability Office on the repatriation effort last year said that poor training and bureaucratic infighting left Americans unsafe.
content: WASHINGTON — The government’s confused effort to retrieve Americans overseas during the early weeks of the coronavirus pandemic compromised the safety of the evacuees, federal employees and communities where they returned, according to a report published on Monday by Congress’s nonpartisan watchdog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel plans a testing program to let children go where the vaccinated can.
description: With a negative test, those under 16 will be allowed access to sporting and religious events in lieu of a vaccination certificate.
content: When Israel instituted its Green Pass system last month, granting fully vaccinated people access to sports, cultural and other leisure events and gathering places, it did not offer an immediate solution for those under 16, who are not yet eligible to receive any Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Flour Sack Towels With Flowery Appeal
description: A line of kitchen helpers, printed with photographs from Pauline Stevens and quotes from writers, arrives just in time for Mother’s Day.
content: The soft cotton that once went into making flour sacks is what the photographer Pauline Stevens has selected for her vibrant collection of kitchen towels decorated with her food-focused photographs.  Each is also printed with a literary quotation or a recipe for a dish, a drink or a sauce, most well-suited for Mother’s Day giving. There’s a special set for the holiday. One of the towels, showing a bucket of roses, has a quote from E.M. Forster: “I am sure that if mothers of various nations could meet, there would be no more wars.” The other towel in the set also has roses, and a quote from Maya Angelou. Both measure 19-by-27 inches. Most of the towels are 27-inches square and come nicely packaged with a greeting card.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: We Were Born to Be Wild
description: Earth Day is a reminder that we are living creatures all the same.
content: To get from my bedroom to the coffeepot every morning, I pass a bank of windows that overlooks two feeders and a birdbath. My early-morning habit is to stand there for a bit, starting the day with my avian neighbors. If it’s migration season, as it is now, I get my coffee and come back for a longer stay, just in case an exotic visitor has arrived during the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Emergent BioSolutions halts operations at its Baltimore plant, where J.&J. doses were ruined, at the F.D.A.’s request.
description: The Times had reported that production of new batches of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine would be put on hold while the review was underway.
content: Emergent BioSolutions, the company whose Baltimore manufacturing facility ruined up to 15 million doses of the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine, said Monday that it has temporarily shut down operations at the plant at the request of the Food and Drug Administration and acknowledged that the company must make improvements to “restore confidence” in its work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Battle Over Super League Begins With Letters, Threats and Banners
description: The founding members of a league that would reshape soccer have warned the sport’s leaders that they will fight any effort to block their plans.
content: LONDON — The superclubs have called in the lawyers. The president of European soccer has responded, calling the teams’ leaders “snakes and liars.” And the fans want no part of any of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Helper for Eastern Orthodox Easter
description: The cookbook author Diane Kochilas now sells grape leaves from Crete for dolmas and fish.
content: This year, Eastern Orthodox Easter comes on May 2. In a run-up to the celebration, there are some ingredients for traditional dishes that are worth having on hand, notably grape leaves, used for enclosing fillings to make dolmas (vine leaves stuffed with grains, meat or seafood) or to wrap fish before baking. The Greek food expert Diane Kochilas has recently added organic grape leaves from Crete to her website, along with recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Political Sectarianism Is a Growing Threat to American Democracy
description: The country is increasingly split into camps that don’t just disagree on policy and politics — they see the other as alien, immoral, a threat. Such political sectarianism is now on the march.
content: American democracy faces many challenges: New limits on voting rights. The corrosive effect of misinformation. The rise of domestic terrorism. Foreign interference in elections. Efforts to subvert the peaceful transition of power. And making matters worse on all of these issues is a fundamental truth: The two political parties see the other as an enemy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Source for Smoked Trout
description: Idaho rainbow trout is the latest release from Fishwife Tinned Seafood Co.
content: With their eyes on Spain and Portugal (and the value given tinned seafood there), Caroline Goldfarb, a comedy television writer, and Becca Millstein, who worked in the entertainment industry, decided that better domestic canned choices were needed. Now they’re in the fish business as founders of Fishwife Tinned Seafood Co. Its latest release is Idaho rainbow trout lightly smoked over alder wood in Oregon and canned in sweet little toothpick-friendly chunks in olive oil, garlic, salt and brown sugar. A plate of it with green olives and a bottle of California albariño, and you’re good to go. Trout salad, trout tossed over pasta or added to a bowl of ramen are some other options. The trout joins their smoked domestic albacore tuna. The rainbow trout is sustainably farmed, and their albacore tuna is wild-caught.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Corporate Donations Changed After the Capitol Riot
description: New fund-raising disclosures show a shift in giving.
content: After the January 6 riot at the Capitol, scores of companies vowed to pause their political donations. Some stopped giving to all politicians, while others shunned only those 147 Republicans who voted to overturn the presidential election results. A recent deadline for candidates to release fund-raising details for the first quarter revealed more details about how corporate giving has changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: With ‘Knives Out’ Deal, Netflix Signals It’s in the Franchise Business
description: The streaming gold rush of 2017-18, when Netflix scooped up big-name television creators, now seems to have migrated to the film world.
content: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood let out a collective gasp this month when it was announced that Netflix had spent about $465 million to buy two sequels to the quirky surprise 2019 hit “Knives Out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Diamond
title: The Pandemic Helped Me Realize How Essential My Routines Are
description: By setting routines for myself, I was able to shield myself from chaos. Then the pandemic happened. I set out to get them back on track.
content: This article is part of a series on resilience in troubled times — what we can learn about it from history and personal experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Kimon de Greef
title: Wildfire Deals Hard Blow to South Africa’s Archives
description: The fire, which began Sunday and is still being fought, ravaged a library that housed first-edition books, films, photographs and other primary sources documenting Southern African history.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Firefighters in Cape Town battled a wildfire on Monday that had engulfed the slopes of the city’s famed Table Mountain and destroyed parts of the University of Cape Town’s library, a devastating blow to the world’s archives of Southern African history.

content: New York has just spent $1.5 billion to entice very large groups of people to gather under the same roof. When will that seem like a good idea again?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Supreme Court’s Increasingly Dim View of the News Media

content: WASHINGTON — Last month, in a dissent in a routine libel case, a prominent federal judge lashed out at the news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Bad Future, Better Future’
description: In this lesson, students will explore an unconventional approach to reporting on climate change: a children’s book. Then, using the book as a mentor text, they will create their own illustrated guide for young readers.
content: This Lesson of the Day will help prepare students to participate in our live panel discussion about climate change, on April 22 at 1 p.m. Eastern time.

title: NASA’s Mars Helicopter Completes First Flight on Another Planet
description: The brief test of the experimental vehicle called Ingenuity shows how explorers can study the red planet from the sky as well as the ground.
content: A small robotic helicopter named Ingenuity made space exploration history on Monday when it lifted off the surface of Mars and hovered in the wispy air of the red planet. It was the first machine from Earth ever to fly like an airplane or a helicopter on another world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Takeaways from the closing arguments of the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: Prosecutors and the defense made their final pitches to the jury.
content: After three weeks of testimony from 45 witnesses, the lawyers gave their concluding arguments on Monday in the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murdering George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: John Grisham Leaves the Courtroom for Basketball, and Sudan

content: There is a basketball term to describe the author John Grisham: volume shooter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Daniel Politi
title: ‘We Were Left With Nothing’: Argentina’s Misery Deepens in the Pandemic
description: The economy contracted by nearly 10 percent last year, and the country faces a reckoning with the I.M.F. over $45 billion in debts.
content: Before the pandemic, Carla Huanca and her family were making modest but meaningful improvements to their cramped apartment in the slums of Buenos Aires.

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Will Wright
title: Little has been said about the $20 bill that brought officers to the scene.
description: George Floyd used it to buy cigarettes, but a store clerk thought it was fake. Neither side in the trial has spent much time addressing it.
content: The last three weeks of the Derek Chauvin trial provided jurors with a comprehensive understanding of George Floyd’s final moments, pieced together from hours of video and witness testimony. But there is one part of the case that lawyers for both sides have spent little time on: the $20 bill that brought the police to the scene in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: October Comes Early for Dodgers and Padres
description: A weekend series between N.L. West titans didn’t disappoint. But San Diego, after years of playing second (or third or fourth) fiddle, has a lot to prove.
content: SAN DIEGO — In April there is no red, white and blue bunting hanging anywhere quite yet, but you could have fooled San Diego’s most enthusiastic baseball fans over the weekend. They streamed into the Gaslamp Quarter and Petco Park clothed in brown and mustard, limited only by their imaginations.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Michael Gold
title: New Yorkers can soon get vaccinated under the natural history museum’s big blue whale.
description: Starting Friday, all New York City residents will be eligible to receive a coronavirus vaccine at the American Museum of Natural History.
content: New Yorkers will soon be able to get vaccinated against the coronavirus under the 94-foot-long model of a blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday, as the museum — long popular with tourists and students on field trips — is set to be one of the city’s newest mass vaccination sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s Rerecorded ‘Fearless’ Is the Year’s Biggest Debut So Far
description: “Fearless (Taylor’s Version)” opened with the equivalent of 291,000 sales in the United States, giving her a third No. 1 album in just under nine months.
content: In the summer of 2019, after Taylor Swift’s first six albums were sold as part of a deal for her original record company, an idea was floated — by Kelly Clarkson, no less — that seemed an unlikely lark: that Swift could rerecord replicas of those albums, in part as revenge against investors who had traded her creative work like real estate. (Something that, to be fair, happens almost daily in the music business.)

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Why the Worst N.B.A. Player Is (Probably) Still Better Than You
description: There’s confidence, and then there’s thinking you can beat one of the 500 (N.B.A.) or 150 (W.N.B.A.) best basketball players in the world.
content: Of the millions of people around the world who play basketball, fewer than 500 are in the N.B.A. at any given time. Fewer than 150 are in the W.N.B.A. Before retiring in 2012, Brian Scalabrine spent 11 seasons in the N.B.A., far more than the majority of players who have made it to that level. He won a championship as a reserve for the Boston Celtics in 2008. He is 6-foot-9 and roughly 250 pounds.

title: Tell Me the One About the Presidential Candidate Who Ran for Mayor
description: Or the mayor who ran for president.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, you’re a New Yorker and I’m now a former New Yorker, albeit one who is often in town. How are you feeling about the city these days? And do you have any preferences in the race to succeed Bill de Blasio?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Families are reunited as Australia and New Zealand begin their travel bubble.
description: Thousands of passengers were able to move freely between the two countries for the first time in a year, prompting celebrations both official and personal.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — Airports in Australia and New Zealand were filled with emotional scenes on Monday as thousands of passengers were allowed to travel freely between the two countries for the first time in more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Yang Lands Last Place on Ballot: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race
description: The ballot order for the June 22 New York mayoral primary was decided by lottery, not alphabetical order, but Andrew Yang will still appear last.
content: Much of the focus in the New York City mayoral race has been given to the eight best-known Democratic candidates, who lead in fund-raising and in early polling. But on the June 22 primary ballot, none of the eight will appear at the top; that honor will go to a more obscure candidate.

description: The New York governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, is now the subject of four separate investigations into his behavior in office.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — The New York State attorney general has opened an investigation into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s use of state resources as he wrote and promoted his recent pandemic memoir, the latest inquiry to engulf the embattled three-term Democrat.

title: A Difficult Diplomatic Triangle
description: A nuclear deal with Iran is central to President Biden’s foreign policy. So why did one of the United States’ closest allies apparently just try to blow it up?

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Ed Augustin
title: A Cuba Without a Castro? A Country Steps Into the Unknown.
description: Raúl Castro has stepped down as head of Cuba’s Communist Party, leaving Cubans without a Castro to lead them for the first time in over 60 years.
content: When Raúl Castro retired as Cuba’s top leader Monday, he left a warning for a nation increasingly divided over the legacy of its Communist revolution: The choice at hand is continuity of the revolution’s ideals, or defeat.

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What’s the Secret of Biden’s Success?
description: The president’s party is finally comfortable in its own skin.
content: Stop me if you’ve heard this one before: A new Democratic president has inherited a nation in crisis. His first major policy initiative is a short-term relief bill intended to lead the way out of that crisis. He follows that bill with proposals to address longer-term problems and, if possible, to change American society for the better. His party holds majorities in the House and the Senate, but both of his initiatives face scorched-earth opposition from Republicans.

title: A Quiet Arms Race Is Rapidly Heating Up Between the Two Koreas
description: The buildup over the last few years has threatened the delicate balance of peace on the Korean Peninsula.
content: SEOUL — Pride and jealousy have driven North and South Korea to engage in propaganda shouting matches and compete over who could build a taller flagpole on their border. Now that one-upmanship is intensifying a much more dangerous side of their rivalry: the arms race.

description: As the subject of no fewer than three biographies since her death in 1995, the popular writer lived a complicated, if fascinating, life. What was she really like?
content: This article is part of T’s Book Club, a series of essays and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation about “The Talented Mr. Ripley,” to be led by Edmund White and held on April 22.

description: Mr. McGuire has landed endorsements from Representative Gregory W. Meeks and three hip-hop giants as his campaign for New York mayor enters a crucial phase.

title: Aleksei Navalny Is Transferred to Hospital for Vitamin Treatment
description: The high-profile Russian opposition leader has been on hunger strike for nearly three weeks. The U.S. has warned of “consequences” should he die.
content: MOSCOW — The Russian authorities moved the imprisoned opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to a hospital on Monday for what was described as treatment with vitamins.

content: BERLIN — Germany’s top two parties announced their candidates for chancellor on Monday and early Tuesday morning, with the Greens sending their dynamic but inexperienced leader, Annalena Baerbock, 40, into the running against Armin Laschet, 60, the head of the largest conservative party, who triumphed after a divisive public power struggle.

title: Fleeing a Modern War, Syrians Seek Refuge in Ancient Ruins
description: So many people have fled to Syria’s crowded northwest that families have settled in important archaeological sites. “We, too, have become ruins.”
content: AL-KFEIR, Syria — As the sun set, children in dirty clothes and battered shoes herded sheep past the towering stone walls of a Byzantine settlement abandoned more than 1,000 years ago, leading them into an ancient cave nearby where the animals would spend the night.

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Whimsical Chocolate Shop for the North Fork
description: The pastry chef Ursula Sala-Illa, a.k.a. Ursula XVII, sells bonbons, bars and cookies at Atelier Disset in Cutchogue, N.Y.
content: Ursula Sala-Illa, who prefers to be known as Ursula XVII, has just opened her own chocolate shop, Atelier Disset, on the North Fork of Long Island. The pastry chef’s complicated nomenclature has to do with her Catalonian roots. In the Catalan language “disset” means 17 (pronounce it and if you know French, you’ll also understand). Ursula XVII — a native New Yorker who worked at Ai Fiori in New York and with Albert Adrià and Oriol Balaguer in Spain — has settled on the North Fork. On its website and in-store, the compact little shop sells finely crafted and decorated bonbon assortments with fillings like coconut marzipan and banana walnut, assorted bars and chunky cookies. Eventually she plans to hold workshops.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Water in Alaska, Where Salmon Fishing Dreams Live On
description: Each summer, salmon begin their journey back to the rivers where they were spawned. Alaskan fishermen, along with whales, eagles and bears, share in the abundance.
content: My camera lens is pressed against the window of the small floatplane as it flies below a thick ceiling of clouds. The mist clings to the hillsides of a temperate rainforest that descend steeply to the rocky coastline of southeast Alaska.

description: All American adults in every state are now eligible for a Covid-19 vaccine.

content: A hint of optimism has been added to the Climate Clock, the set of decreasing numbers on the facade of a building in New York’s Union Square that was conceived by two artists and activists, to communicate the urgency of curbing carbon emissions.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: New Week! New Recipes!
description: Make the latest from Melissa Clark, Yotam Ottolenghi and more.
content: Good morning.
